content: try it on again and make sure it is tight/loose enough i recommend placing your decreases/increases where the corners of the yoke had been this will hide the seam under your arm fiddle with the distance between the decreases/increases if the resulting circumference of the sleeve does not fit for ~10 rounds double_crochet in each stitch around sl to first stitch ch2 turn try the sweater on again it should reach to just after your elbow add or remove more rounds so that it reaches this point make sure you keep count of the number of rounds you add so that you can repeat it on the other side you can skip these next decreases if you don t mind a wider sleeve if you want it tighter around your forearm add two decreases to each row one on each side of the sleeve until it has reached your desired circumference you may also try adding just one decrease per row if the two decreases taper too quickly for you this section may take some trial and error but that is what allows it to be customized again for ~10 rounds double_crochet in each stitch around sl to first stitch ch2 turn try the sweater on again it should reach to just before your wrist add or remove more rounds so that it reaches this point make sure you keep count of the number of rounds you add so that you can repeat it on the other side now you are going to start adding the v part of the sleeve put your sweater on and mark the stitch that is closest to the line extending from your middle finger you can also use your index or ring finger if that s where you prefer the point of the v to end double_crochet in each stitch around until you reach the marked stitch in the marked stitch do a double_crochet ch1 double_crochet double_crochet to end of the round sl to first double_crochet ch2 turn for the final rounds you will double_crochet around until you reach the ch1 space where you will start placing dc2 ch1 dc2 this will create a sharper point on the sleeve allowing it to reach your fingers sooner so that it doesn t cover your entire palm double_crochet to the end of the round sl to first double_crochet ch2 turn if you want to keep the sleeve tighter around your hand decrease by 2 or 4 stitches each round keep adding these rounds with the dc2 ch1 dc2 group in each chain space until the point of the v reaches the knuckle of your middle finger or index or ring finger to finish your sleeve complete one round with single_crochet instead of double_crochet when you reach the ch1 space do a group of single_crochet ch6 single_crochet in the space try on your sweater again and make sure the ch6 fits around your finger add or subtract chains as needed if you do not want to be
